title: Wednesday, 14th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hi. Hello. Welcome.

BE11:05am

Have a portrait.

BE11:05am

11:05 am
BE11:06am

That's Jean Paul and Martine Clozel, co-founders of Actelion.

BE11:06am

.... Picture from the Ernst & Young World Entrepreneur Of The Year 2008 awards ....

BE11:07am

And I've just noticed is copyright to Ken Lennox, who will hopefully bill E&Y for usage rather than us: https://www.flickr.com/photos/kenlennox/

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Ken Lennox, for all your photography needs! And Ernst & Young, for all your World Entrepreneur Of The Year needs! There we go, that should help.

BE11:08am

So, J&J walked overnight.

BE11:09am

Price too high, is the theory. Though whether any price would be acceptable to the Clozels is the unknown here.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Sanofi steps in, but the odds on it putting together a better proposal without a specific need to Actelion to seek a white knight look pretty slim.

BE11:10am

Full story: https://www.ft.com...-81c2-f57d90f6741a

BE11:11am

And have some Deutsche as well.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

At this stage, it remains difficult to gauge any potential interest from Sanofi given only modest strategic overlap and a likely high acquisition price. However, the company has
previously stated it is potentially looking for mid-sized M&A and, we believe, at least cosmetically a potential deal could be made to be double-digit EPS accretive if not immediately obvious on value accretion.

BE11:11am

Significant EPS accretion possible; overlap in MS could be a potential attraction

We believe a potential acquirer could be able to drive Actelion’s EBIT margin to ~50% (from its current 35%) by eliminating duplicated corporate overhead cost and reducing R&D spend (approximately €350m of synergy). We believe this would allow Sanofi to make a potential transaction in the region of 10% or
greater accretive to outer year Business EPS even at a price of CHF270/share (based on a 2-3% cost of debt). Although it is unlikely that a third party could extract more value from a deal than J&J given limited sales and marketing synergies with the PAH franchise, the overlap between Actelion’s pipeline (ponesimod in multiple sclerosis) and Sanofi’s marketed franchise could be a
potential attraction. However, to make this potential deal exceed Sanofi’s WACC of 7.9% by 2022E, on our calculations the company would be required to extract c.€650m of synergy (or additional profits driven from sales).

BE11:11am

Significant pipeline or synergy value implied at greater than CHF250/share

Our NPV analysis suggests Actelion’s cash flows from the PAH franchise out to patent expiry could be worth around CHF145 to a potential acquirer, with an additional CHF30/share achievable in bull cases for Uptravi sales of ~CHF2.5bn As such a price of greater than CHF250 assumes that Actelion can ultimately offset the patent expiries of Opsumit and Uptravi over 2026-27 by delivering on its pipeline and/or extracting significant synergy from the business.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:13am

A potential transaction could take different forms, in our view. As we wrote here, potential costs synergies from Actelion would range from CHF30/share (assuming elimination of most R&D costs) to CHF80/share (assuming elimination of R&D, G&A and some Sales costs). A reduction in the existing cost base of 30-40% (close to recent transactions in the sector) would represent SFr400-500m annually (the entire R&D budget plus ~10% of SG&A), i.e. around SFr320-425m post tax annually. We flag that any potential bidder could not simultaneously secure the full potential synergies and the pipeline (valued CHF25 in our bull case). Several companies theoretically have the ability to integrate Actelion's activities, given its relatively focused area of expertise. Companies with activities in respiratory and cardiology could plausibly be interested, based on potential overlap. Hence we could see potential bidders interested only in some parts (the PAH franchise, the pipeline, other smaller rare disease products). As a reminder, Actelion CEO Jean Paul Clozel has been a strong proponent of the value of the pipeline, which is not reflected in consensus valuations. The main pipeline assets include ponesimod in phase 3 in multiple sclerosis, trialed against Sanofi's Aubagio, the antibiotic cadazolid in phase 2, and the insomnia drug DORA in phase 2 (follow up of almorexant, terminated a few years ago for toxicity reasons).

BE11:13am

(@Binocular: that's more of a feature than a bug.)

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Strong execution in 2016, ahead of US generic launches in 2017. As a reminder, Actelion's strong outperformance YTD has been driven by delayed US generics of Tracleer and strong launches of Opsumit and Uptravi. While US generics of Tracleer are widely expected in early 2017, we stand close to consensus on both Opsumit (2020 sales of CHF1.4bn) and Uptravi (2020 sales of CHF1.4bn), and see more limited room for further EPS upgrades.

BE11:15am

We should be applauding the Clozels, right?

BE11:16am

Not only do they see more intangible value to its pipeline than J&J, they're prepared to wear the risk.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Normally, such management confidence is a bad sign -- we can go through the list of bid rejections, if we must -- but in this case it's the founders arguing they have a superior understanding of the business.

BE11:18am

They've been right in the past. And if they're wrong now, that ugly award in the picture can be melted down and sold for scrap.

undefined
11:18 am
BE11:18am

To London, then.

BE11:19am

FTSE off a bit, Fed later.

BE11:19am

Oh, while I remember ......

11:20 am
BE11:20am

BE11:20am

There you go. Yellen Live, starting 2pm EST (which is five hours ahead, right?)

BE11:21am

For now, we'll get on with other stuff.

11:21 am
Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 349.50, down 17.2 (-4.69%), High: 371.40, Low: 339.20, Volume: 4.47m
BE11:22am

Decent run into results, which turned out to be a bit boring.

BE11:22am

Numbers are pretty much in line, guidance is unchanged.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Conference call went okay .... It's a big fall on nothing much.

BE11:23am

"Travel and arrive" seems to be the common explanation among the sellside.

BE11:23am

Morgan Stanley incoming.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

- Headline FY H1 Pre Tax Profits have come in at £144m (versus a consensus £141m and up 19% on the equivalent period last year). Group FY Q2 LFLs have come in at 4% (versus a consensus of 3%). We suspect, therefore, that the many bulls on the stock will argue that this is a good outcome and demonstrates that trading remains robust following the Brexit referendum.

BE11:23am

- We think it worth flagging, however, that statutory profits (£104m) are again considerably weaker than headline profits and that UK LfLs (which contributed most of the group's LfL) were boosted by 4% as a result of sales transference from store closures.

BE11:23am

- As expected, there is no quantitative update on current trading. The outlook statement says simply: "we remain optimistic about our ability to gain market share", and there is no mention of trading performance over the Black Friday weekend. Dixons Carphone, though, remains a very seasonal business, and trading over the next 3-4 weeks is key to the group's full year profit outcome. - There appears to be only one piece of 'new news' here on strategy – a tie-up with SSE to "build and trial new connected product and service propositions through 2017, paving the way for a consumer launch thereafter". Although in line with management's strategy to build the CWS division into a material profit generator for the group, we suspect that this announcement lacks sufficient detail at this stage to attract much investor excitement.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

- Although it is unlikely to get much attention, we think it is also worth flagging that the group's pension deficit (on an IAS 19 basis) has risen to £646 million (vs £423m at the Interims last year).

BE11:24am

- Having spoken to the company this morning, we think it unlikely that consensus forecasts will move much in response to today's statement. According to Bloomberg, consensus is looking for FY 2016/17 Headline Pre Tax Profits in FY 2016/17 of £488m (giving EPS of 30.7p)

BE11:24am

- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Dixons Carphone is trading on 11.5x Cal 2017 earnings, 6.5x EBITDA with a 3.0% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.8x, 7.8x, and 3.8% respectively.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

I passed the Carphone Warehouse in Westfield a week or so ago. It's empty. As in, they don't seem to have enough stuff to fill the floorspace.

BE11:26am

It's a bit like a cheap version of one of those minimalist shops off New Bond Street that display a single handbag perched on a white laminate pillar.

BE11:26am

Anyway, conference call was 9pm. Exane summarises like this:

11:26 am
BE11:26am

On the conference call, DC management highlighted the positive momentum in the business, defended against the headwinds from input cost inflation, pointed towards the variable cost base that can shield against market declines and reiterated confidence in the CWS business. Momentum in the last quarter was fuelled by mobile, but subsequent peak weeks around Black Friday were encouraging across consumer electronics. Price rises on Apple products haven’t been met with a negative volume response, and whilst management don’t want to extrapolate that trend, they do believe the lower price visibility and comparability in electricals offers protection. Were price rises or the macro environment to drive a declining market, management argued that sales are made at a c.10-11% drop-through margin, meaning any headwind would be manageable.

BE11:27am

Finally, little detail was offered on the SSE partnership and the Sprint roll-out has been modestly slower than anticipated, but nonetheless this remains a business management are excited about. Together – there was really little in the way of negative news today. The shares, having run well into numbers have reversed those gains, with today’s results being (as we had feared) viewed as the final, or perhaps penultimate hurrah before 2017 difficulties. That looks harsh to ourselves, but with the shares and valuation back towards post-Brexit averages, it is difficult to point to a near-term catalyst to recover today’s declines.

BE11:28am

As a sidebar, I've heard a few complaints about Curry's-PC World being a bit over-aggressive with the Care Plan upselling recently.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

One assumes they know what they're doing, given previous issues with such policies.

undefined
BE11:31am

Wow, it's slow today.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

And it's only going to get worse from here.

BE11:32am

The run-up to Christmas will be particularly bad this year, I suspect, given we have a theoretical five-day working week next week.

BE11:32am

Let's keep plodding on, though.

11:32 am
Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 2,259, up 129 (+6.06%), High: 2,264, Low: 2,170, Volume: 569.48k
BE11:04am

This is Markets Live. FT Alphaville's dunno, whatever.

BE11:35am

Results are fine. Slightly better than hoped.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Organic growth beats guidance.

BE11:36am

(Baffled by what Micro Focus could call organic growth, given it's a rollup, but whatever.)

BE11:36am

Divi increased.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Guidance stays as is.

BE11:37am

UBS has one of its blipvert summaries.

BE11:37am

A: MCRO reported H1 growth of 1.2% (FY 16: -2.0%) with SUSE growing 23.3% (FY 16: 18.2%) and the core portfolio shrinking 3.6% (FY 16: -6.1%). In the core, licences grew 0.2% (FY 16: -4.8%). Underlying adjusted EBITDA grew 6% to $320m/46.8% (cons. $320m/UBS $309m). Operating cash flow of $202m was up 24% y/y.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Notwithstanding easy comparatives, COBOL saw 14% growth, with licences +30% (H1 16: -16%). Group-wide, mgt noted good execution in N America and a better UK and France offset weakness in Brazil. Underlying OpEx fell $17m y/y to $359m despite SUSE investments continuing, driving "core" EBITDA margins to 49.7% (+320bp y/y).

BE11:38am

(COBOL! The core business of Britain's second-biggest publicly owned technology company is COBOL. A programming language that's older than Kevin Spacey. ....)

BE11:39am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Guidance for (2)-0% LFL growth is unchanged (cons. -1.2%). Cons. is modelling a 7% increase (H1: 6%) in adjusted u/lying adjusted EBITDA to $659m for the year.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Cons. EBITDA seems unlikely to move, but the topline result should be well received.

BE11:40am

And Barclays.

BE11:40am

The better top-line was driven by a Core Micro Focus at -3.6% YoY and strong results from SUSE (+23.3%). The core was down 6.1% for FY16 with accelerating declines in 2H (-6.9%) and this is therefore an excellent result driven by reduction in the rate of decline in maintenance and consultancy. SUSE reported +18.2% for FY16 and this accelerated to 22.4% in 2H16. It is encouraging that it had a further step up to this level.

The only niggle is the high level of exceptionals at $41m but we expect that this is impacted by HPE. We expect that it has started HPE Software workstream and there is therefore a real chance that the asset will be delivered with a better profit profile than we expected. For the 2H it anticipates a further $80m in charges.

EPS was 8.2% ahead of our estimate and this was due to higher operating profit and lower interest costs.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

The stock trades at 10x our discounted FY20E pro-forma EPS. Given that a large part of the synergies won’t come through before FY20, we use FY20 as our valuation year but discount it back one year to have a valuation year in-line with the rest of our coverage.

undefined
BE11:41am

So ............

11:40 am
BE11:41am

https://twitter.com/MarkKleinmanSky/status/808999262696669185

Punch Taverns PLC (PUB:LSE): Last: 129.38, up 0.875 (+0.68%), High: 130.00, Low: 126.00, Volume: 74.18k
BE11:41am

Up 8% live.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

We'd been chasing similar stuff last week (I know there's no point in telling you this now, sorry) but shied away from mentioning largely because Punch equity is such a negligible part of the EV.

BE11:43am

Full story here: http://news.sky.co...cmp=snt-sf-twitter

BE11:43am

Mr McIntosh, who is said to be working with advisers at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, is understood to have pitched an offer at more than 180p-a-share, while Heineken's bid may have been marginally below that level, sources said.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Hm. I'd like to see more clarity on capital structure here.

BE11:45am

Punch's net debt was 6.6x EBITDA at the last set of numbers.

BE11:45am

With a LTV of 58%.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

That's the reason you've got the stock trading nowhere near its NAV of 382p a share.

BE11:47am

Anyway, with Kleinman putting the tale out there one would expect a statement in time. Too late to chase now though, I suspect.

undefined
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Speaking of rumourtrage .....

BE11:48am

Some rumblings of late around Asda and Wal-Mart

BE11:50am

It's familiar stuff, mostly. As in, how long will Wal-Mart put up with Asda being rubbish?

11:50 am
BE11:50am

The current suggestion is the "profit holiday" one.

BE11:50am

As in, Asda gets one last chance to sort itself out.

BE11:51am

One year to turn things around, most likely by turning up the heat on pricing.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

We went through this argument most recently here: https://www.ft.com...-ba7d-76378e4fef24

BE11:52am

(@Pharma: no, I mean rubbish as in having passed £2bn of sales to its direct rivals over the past 24 months, which I imagine wasn't in management's performance plan.)

BE11:53am

All just sector gossip, I underline. But a proper, actual price war would make the supermarkets rather more fun again. Sector's been a bit dull and rational of late.

11:53 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 206.95, up 2.1 (+1.03%), High: 208.55, Low: 204.55, Volume: 8.14m
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 249.20, up 3.4 (+1.38%), High: 250.10, Low: 244.80, Volume: 3.92m
undefined
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Huh.

BE11:55am

Gordon Brown has demanded that Rupert Murdoch’s takeover of the Sky satellite business be delayed until the government carries out the second part of the Leveson inquiry into press malpractice.

In a letter to the culture secretary, Karen Bradley, the former prime minister said the bid by Murdoch-controlled 21st Century Fox for Sky made the “promised but delayed second part of the Leveson inquiry … particularly relevant and timely”

BE11:55am

https://www.thegua...ver-leveson-part-2

11:56 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 985.50, down 2.5 (-0.25%), High: 992.00, Low: 981.00, Volume: 3.66m
BE11:56am

K.

BE11:56am

Struggling a bit with the internal logic of that, but whatever.

11:56 am
undefined
BE11:57am

..... No Punch statement. Yet.

BE11:58am

One assumes they're rushing one out -- or more likely will have one pre-written given the rumour was around last week.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

Live price up 22% at 157p. Folk believe this, and are probably correct to.

BE12:00pm

(@Boncoeur: this doesn't seem to be a problem for anyone except you. While I'm never usually loathe to blame our IT team for stuff, I'm not 100% it's their fault this time.)

BE12:01pm

Anyway, let's wind up. Today's been rubbish, sorry.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Thanks for tuning in. Come back for Cardiff on Janet. 7pm GMT, 2pm EST.

BE12:05pm

(@ROTR: we use Chrome here by default. ML seems to work okay on mine -- version 54.0.2840.99 m -- most of the time, though version proliferation makes testing trickier than it should be.)

BE11:35am

The FTSE 100's other tech champion, with its weird collection of vintage software that it keeps running like steam engines at some nearly abandoned beach resort ....
